summary: This document is an email exchange between prosecutors in the United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell case and Dr. Gail Goodman, a distinguished professor of psychology. The prosecutors express interest in consulting with Dr. Goodman as an expert witness on memory for child sexual abuse, and she responds by attaching several of her research publications.

persons.name: Gail Goodman
persons.role: Distinguished Professor of Psychology, potential expert witness
persons.context: Dr. Goodman is contacted by prosecutors in the Ghislaine Maxwell case regarding potential consultation and testimony as an expert on memory for child sexual abuse. She responds by providing her research articles.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell is mentioned as the subject of the prosecution's outreach to Dr. Goodman for expert testimony.

connections.description: Prosecutors in the Ghislaine Maxwell case seek Dr. Goodman as a potential expert witness to testify about memory for child sexual abuse.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell trial scheduled to begin
events.description: The trial for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled to begin in the Southern District of New York.

keyFacts: Prosecutors in the Ghislaine Maxwell case reached out to Dr. Gail Goodman on November 24, 2021, seeking her as a potential expert witness.
Dr. Goodman is a distinguished professor specializing in research on long-term memory for child sexual abuse experiences.
The Maxwell trial was scheduled to begin on November 29, 2021.
The correspondence indicates the prosecution's preparation to present expert testimony on the psychology of abuse memory.
Dr. Goodman provided several of her research publications to the prosecutors for review.
